reviewText:
Final Fantasy IV: The After YearsDeveloper: Square-Enix
Publisher: Square-Enix

Introduction
==========
This game really makes me wish for some sort of a Neutral Rating on Steam reviews. It's not great, but it's not terrible either. I ultimately decided to give it a positive rating because I want players to focus on the good (which it has loads of) and not the bad (just a few things). Ultimately, it's Steam. If a game has questionable ratings/reviews that make you hold off on taking the plunge and purchasing the game, just wait for a sale. They happen pretty often. With that said, let's move on!

Final Fantasy IV: The After Years is a continuation/sequel to Final Fantasy IV that was originally released as a downloadable title for the Nintendo Wii. Since then it's had a few other releases on various platforms. Taking place 17 years after the events of Final Fantasy IV, it's a great sequel, although it has some major pacing issues. The majority of the game feels like a huge slog, and it really takes a lot of patience to get through. However, once you make it to the last couple of chapters (called Tales), the story payout is huge and the game really starts to shine.

Gameplay
==========
This game is much the same as FFIV, however it is episodic. Not episodic like TellTale Games titles, but more like it plays out in chapters. Each chapter (Tale) centers on a different character and the other characters they join up with, and in the very last Tale they all unite into one huge group that you are able to choose from to tackle the last sections of the game. The biggest draw of this game is the continuation of the story from IV and how each of the original characters has changed and moved on. Some of them have had children, and other characters that crop up are completely new.

The After Years utilizes the same battle system as IV, and it works wonderfully. Don't fix what isn't broke, right? Aside from the pacing issue I mentioned, my only other problem with The After Years is that it's missing a sizeable amount of content from previous versions. Final Fantasy IV Complete for the PSP (includes FF4, FF4 Interlude, and FF4: The After Years) had Challenge Dungeons at the end of EVERY Tale, and over a dozen extra cameo bosses in the final dungeon of the last Tale. While the Challenge Dungeons weren't too too much, and just served as a more efficient way to level your characters in preparation for the last Tale, the extra cameo bosses are a huge loss. The fights featured bosses from other entries in the series, such as the 4 fiends from FF1 (Lich, Tiamat, Marilith, and Kraken), and these fights were a lot of fun. They could probably throw up a patch to add these if they really wanted to, or even add them as DLC, but it's most likely not going to happen.

Another complaint is that most of the game is going through the same areas found in FFIV multiple times. And while this is true, they are all tied into the story to an extent. Each time you run through them with a different set of characters you'll run into different events (as well as refilled and different treasures!!).

A new feature The After Years utilizes is the Moon Phase System. The Moon has 4 distinct phases, and each phase affects certain abilities directly by changing their attack power or effectiveness...which can drastically alter the difficulty of battles. Some rare monsters also only appear during certain Moon phases.

Graphics
==========
Featuring the same 3D graphics as FFIV (they both use the same engine), The After Years looks just as good as its predecessor. This is an upgrade from the 2D graphics the PSP version featured. The new characters that were added look just as good as the original characters as well.

Sound and Music
==========
Frequent readers of mine have probably figured out that I love video game music, and that I like pointing out particularly good tracks in a game's soundtrack. The After Years has one particular track that stands out to me thats used in particular battles against a certain foe.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f3ZRtaQzc04

Amazing. Most of the game reuses tracks from FFIV, but it adds a few new tracks that were composed by Junya Nakano. While different from Uematsu, Nakano has managed to pump out a few memorable tracks that really stand out and fit the game very well. The track above, in particular, manages to capture the wrongness and desperation of the situations it plays in PERFECTLY, and I cannot praise him enough for that.

Performance
==========
The After Years runs on the same engine as FFIV, and as such runs more or less the same. FPS isn't a huge issue for an older classic game like this, and I did not encounter any game-breaking bugs or glitches. I played with a controller the whole time and found it very comfortable. Not much to say here.

Final Thoughts
==========
One of the extremely rare sequels in the franchise, Final Fantasy IV: The After Years delivers a great continuation to a beloved story, although it does suffer from a couple of glaring problems with the gameplay itself. Despite this, fans will undoubtedly find something here to enjoy even if it takes some work and a lot of patience to reach. If you have never played The After Years before but have played FFIV and would like to see what happened to the beloved characters, this would be a great version to try out. If you've played or already own the PSP FFIV collection...stick with that one.

Gameplay Demo
==========
https://youtu.be/gOt6vIDDGS0

Nerd House Verdict:
==========
Recommended

NOTE: Special thanks to my friend Liroku for the gift :)

If you loved the original FF4, you will love The After Years. If you haven't played FF4, finish it first before starting The After Years.

The After Years is most of all a nostalgia trip to 20 years ago, and those of us fortunate enough to have played FF4 back in the early 90's will shed tears of joy playing this game and reliving those golden memories. The storyline folds masterfully together, although not everyone will appreciate breaking it into multiple tales and having to level from scratch every time around. And in that vein, a word of caution is in place: nightmares about Underground Waterway may occur!

The PC port, as mentioned by other reviewers, lacks some content that's present on PSP and WiiWare versions, but if they are out of reach for you the PC version holds its ground just fine. There are a few dialogue hiccups, and twice the game simply has crashed upon entering battle, but thanks to the autosave feature you can pick up right from where things went wrong. Multiple save slots per tale (as opposed to 3 slots for the whole game) is also a very welcome feature.

If FF4 is a 10/10 game for me, The After Years deserves a 9½/10. Highly recommended for fans of SNES era JRPGs.

Initially purchased this because I had played the Wiiware version to completion some time ago, and with my console now dead wanted to return to the FF franchise in general.

Positives

1) The story, as far as I've gotten, is for the most part unchanged up to the first visit to Mysidia. A good thing, they're selling this mostly off nostalgia after all.

On the whole I'll likely finish the game because I loved the original version I played but if you are looking for games that stand up against modern competition? look elsewhere.

The story is set 17 years after the events of Final Fantasy IV, where the main cast has moved on, got a new life, the usual. Chapters are used for gameplay, with each main character and a suporting cast with them. It's very straight lined for you, and the only 'optional' exploration would be to wander various dungeons in said tales. I personally enjoyed this feature, however, it did soon come with a flaw. The tales of each character... They're not really an original story. It seems SE sat down and thought: 'Hey, Final Fantasy X-2 was good. We made a trilogy from Final Fantasy XIII. Why not sequel the only game we've remade about 500 times! Success guaranteed!'
The story might as well have just been Final Fantasy IV all over again, as most of the Tales seem to just copy the events from the previous game. This was a little depressing, as you would expect a new original story. That's not to say the story isn't a good playthrough, as it did have some good cliffhangers and reveals. But in my personal opinion, the story only started to get GOOD at Chapter 8 (Kain's Tale). And then, it just decided to go back down hill. Upon hitting Chapter 10 (Final Tale), the game recycled Final Fantasy bosses. I mean, sure, they COULD have given more background on WHY they appeared, but no. It just seemed like a way to fill in the space between Point A to B.
Personally, I would recommend this game, as I have enjoyed it, despite it's lacking orginal storyline plot. On the other hand, I would say buy with caution. If you loved Final Fantasy IV, then you will most likely enjoy this game.

reviewText:
After playing this game yet again after playing it on the Wii, I once again realized why I disliked this game so much.  Oh where to begin.

First off, I've played every version of FFIV out there (I still have my original SNES cart!) with the exception of the PSP complete collection edition (Which is just the GBA version of FFIV, which I have played, and the Wii version of After Years, which I have on my Wii and some interlude chapter that takes place between the end of FFIV and the After Years, which I could care less about).  I also played the After Years on the Wii, and the only chapter I did not buy at the time was Yang's.

To start, I really do not understand why people are mad at the removal of the bonus dungeons.  The bonus dungeons only purpose was filler in between chapters, because when the game originally came out, we had to wait a month or so between chapters.  So what did we do?  Farm stuff!  There is no point to the dungeons when all the chapters are available unless you really wanted to farm for Admantite.  So this did not bother me.

What bothered me was the complete recycle of the FFIV's story.  Considering that FFIV ended pretty well on it's own, I was really shocked that a sequel was announced.  And curious too.

The After Year's story could be summed up like this;  Take FFIV's original plot, throw it in a blender, add in a few of the main hero's kids plus the dwarf princess and a few ninjas, and bam.  You have After Years.  Almost every thing that happens in the After Years has happened in the main game.  From someone getting Desert Fever to fighting Mombomb to a ♥♥♥♥ poor redemption plot that reflected Cecil's redemption from the original.  And we top off with a big reveal that almost mirrors the horrible Star Ocean 3 reveal.

What the heck happened to the designs of some characters too!?  Why is Rydia running around in a leotard all of a sudden?  What the heck happened to Porom!?  So much freaking pink!  And what's with Rosa's robes too???  Definitely liked the original designs of the characters better, especially Rydia's.

Gameplay wise, it's only okay.  This version is easier than the Wii version.  I rarely had to grind in chapters, though the last chapter, you'll definitely have to grind, especially if you want characters that may be lagging behind in levels.  The Bands are a nice set up, but half the time, I rarely used them.   Summons and Black Magic and certain character's abilities I found worked just as well.

The Moon phase is a neat idea, but is easy exploitable and you can work around it by abusing tents.  Depending on your setup or an upcoming boss, a moon phase is better than another, but again, easy to work in with tent abuse.  The only way this doesn't work is a balanced party, and even then, it's not that much of a deal.

This game really needed the VA FFIV for the DS did, but Square got lazy and gave us the phone port, which had no VA.  Not a deal breaker, but it looks weird in the intro.

I am kinda disappointed but not surprised that a lot of the bonus bosses were taken out.  Though really, the bonus bosses were really only there as a nod to older FFs.  Not a deal breaker for me.

Overall, if you absolutely have to play the After Years, get the PSP version.  If you're an old school FFIV fan though who enjoyed the original story, stay away from the After Years in general.  It spits on the original story, and this is coming from someone whose favorite character in the original story was Kain (There's a reason for me saying that, but I wanted to keep this review spoiler free.  Then again, if you played the original game, you are spoiled for the game anyways).  Just stick to FFIV and pretend the After Years doesn't exist.

reviewText:
I was always a fan of FF4, back in the SNES days. When they made this sequel to it, albeit with the modern 3D graphic polygon style, I felt it was worth the price. Well...

I hate to say it, but this game isn't much fun and it isn't designed any better than someone's starter game on RPGmaker. The paths are linear, recycled, and it's mainly just a rehash of just about everything from FF4, from the plot to the dungeons.

Notably, the fight balance is just awful. You get pre-designed teams that consist of FF4 characters and relatively disinteresting new characters, but the problem comes down to it that the team compositions just stink. For example, the twins from FF4, Palom and Porom, each get their own story episode in this. And apparently they thought it was a great idea to pair mages with other mages, leaving your team in these annoying glass cannon scenarious where lucky hits basically end your adventure and there's nothing you can do but reload and hope it doesn't happen again. And I'm not talking about boss fights, but basic encounters. The enemy's speed for turns is this game is ridiculous. I notice they get about 1.5 to 2 attack actions for every one of mine. Why do basic enemies need to be this quick? Couple this with the fact you almost never have full groups (FF4's combat system worked in that everyone was different and it was almost always a 5 man group) and you're basically playing long dull scenarios with a broken party design.

Crummy battle system aside, the game is just boring. Outside of the team up attacks of the band system, this is just cobbled together left overs of what was a better first title. It doesn't even do FF4 lore any justice. Rydia gets her summon spells removed by the plot so she's just a generic black mage. Porom's story is more about the people around her, than much about herself. And the best one... they turned the dwarf king's daughter into a ganguro girl who doesn't look anything like her people or anyone else in the world. Huh?? These design decisions are nonsensical.

This is a really weak entry in the FF series and it doesn't work any front. The tight forced perspective and the ugly polygon graphics don't do it any favors either. You can easily find better indie RPGs for five dollars or less on here. This painfully generic title has nothing going for it beyond the FF brand slapped onto it. It's a lazy cash grab game that should be avoided and nothing more.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy IV: The After Years is a sequel for a classic game that was originally released (and also set) 17 years after the original. The question is, is it any good?
Well, the short answer is yeah, it was pretty decent. More detailed rambling follows:

First of all, as The After Years is a sequel for Final Fantasy IV, I will assume that you have played at least some release of the original. Otherwise you might want to consider getting that one first.

The After Years is set 17 years after the events of Final Fantasy IV. Story starts with Ceodore, son of Cecil and Rosa, leaving the town of Baron for training. Meanwhile, Baron and various other locations are invaded by a mysterious girl who is after each nation's crystals for an unknown reason.
What is unique about The After Years compared to any other Final Fantasy game is that story is actually told through ten separate Tales, each told from different character's point of view. As the game progresses, these separate stories start to gradually connect with each other and the main story starts to get clearer. I actually quite liked this way of doing things because it was something different from what I was used to with other Final Fantasy games. The story and writing in The After Years are also actually fairly good, and in my opinion actually better than in Final Fantasy IV.

Along with the original cast of Final Fantasy IV, The After Years introduces a fairly huge roster of new characters, and many of those new characters are actually quite likeable and well written. Many old familiar characters such as Kain, Edward, Parom, and Polom (hey, those two are 22 and not 5 now!) also receive more welcome character development.
Admittedly when an RPG has such a huge character roster as The After Years does, there is almost bound to be some throwaway stock characters, such as bunch of ninjas from Edge's Tale in the After Years.

With the addition of Band abilities, skills performed with two or more characters together, the combat system of The After Years is your same old turn-based ATB gauge system you know from many other Final Fantasy games, so there is really nothing more to say about it. It's good, just don't expect any huge changes to the original like you might have seen in Final Fantasy X-2 for example.

What about the port and cut content? Well, the Steam release is a quick Android port. What this means is that you are still stuck with your 30 FPS (and 15 FPS in combat, just like in the Steam release of Final Fantasy IV), uglier UI, and missing content when compared to Wii and PSP releases of the game. Visually it looks like a PS1 era game, which honestly is something I personally don't really mind but I realize that there are people for whom that is a problem.
Missing content includes challenge dungeons for different characters and an extended final dungeon with cameo bosses from other Final Fantasy games. While this is regrettable, I must say that even the current final dungeon drags on so darn long and frankly, I was quite sick of it towards the end, so I was just glad that it was not an even longer version of it. But it is still missing content and especially people who have played that content before will most likely miss it if they decided to pick up the game here.

So, did I like it? Well, yeah, I did. While not perfect, The After Years does lot of things right and it was fairly enjoyable. However, while I liked it, I never got that Oh man

reviewText:
I'd like to consider myself something of a critic in regards to JRPGs, as far too many have stereotypically bland plots, environments, and characters. If you can't tell it apart from its predecessors in regards to gameplay, it's not worth a good review, or any comment for that matter. That's why I had to stick up for this one, especially since FF4, this game's prequel, was markedly less interesting.

For one, the episodic nature of the game (not in the present-day sense of splitting up games needlessly into multiple cashgrabby installments) gives the story surprising depth. Each character is cast as a protagonist in their own 'tale', left to interpret and respond to the overall game's events differently. They have their own strengths, challenges, and settings that make adapting enjoyably difficult. And to make it all worthwhile, in the endgame you can reselect your favorite combinations to take on the final struggles.

The combat system saw a subtle revamp that considerably smoothed gameplay compared to FF4. The newgame+ feature was also buffed enough to give the game actual replay value, and for once you got the refreshing feeling that nothing was truly missable. Except maybe summons. It's definitely worth at least a single playthrough anyway, and experience with the first game is not required as many of the main plot points relevant to After Years are covered in cutscenes.
